page.title: 04Landscape and Wildlife
page.content: The River Otter rises in the Blackdown Hills, at Otterhead Lakes and flows North of Honiton. The water is very clear. Fly fishermen fish for natural brown trout, some sea trout and stocked rainbow trout. The river and bankside vegetation supports a rich insect population. This is one reason for the quality of the trout. The river has a mayfly hatch. Butterflies are common including the small blue. Badgers are seen regularly along its banks as are deer. The otter is possibly extinct on the river but the mink, an escapee from fur farms is now a pest. The National Trust Combe Wood is noted for wildflowers particularly for bluebells and primroses. Its mixed woodland supports many species of birds.
